articles.headline: Heart Scans Still Covered by Medicare
articles.snippet: The federal government reversed course and said Wednesday it would continue to cover the use of an increasingly popular procedure to detect heart disease.
articles.abstract: The federal government reversed course and said Wednesday it would continue to cover the use of an increasingly popular procedure to detect heart disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reversing a proposed decision issued in December, the federal government said Wednesday it would continue to cover the use of an increasingly popular procedure to detect heart disease.

articles.headline: French Police Questioning Bank Worker
articles.snippet: Authorities took a second employee at the French bank Société Générale into custody in connection with a $7 billion trading scandal.
articles.abstract: Authorities took a second employee at the French bank Société Générale into custody in connection with a $7 billion trading scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Authorities took a second employee at the French bank Société Générale into custody on Wednesday in connection with a trading scandal that the bank said had cost it nearly 5 billion euros (more than $7 billion).

articles.headline: New Inspections Ground 38 Southwest Jets
articles.snippet: The episode raises further questions about Southwest’s maintenance procedures and about oversight by the Federal Aviation Administration.
articles.abstract: The episode raises further questions about Southwest’s maintenance procedures and about oversight by the Federal Aviation Administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines, combing through its maintenance files after being fined $10.2 million last week for an inspection lapse uncovered in 2007, said it found another problem and grounded 38 planes Wednesday, canceling about 125 flights.

articles.headline: Democrats Face Racial Issue Again
articles.snippet: A comment by Geraldine A. Ferraro, a close ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton, has put race at the center of the contest.
articles.abstract: A comment by Geraldine A. Ferraro, a close ally of Hillary Rodham Clinton, has put race at the center of the contest.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the Democratic primary in South Carolina turned racially divisive in January, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama essentially declared a truce and put a stop to fighting between their camps. But this week, race has once again begun casting a pall over the battle between the two.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny
